title: 114_s1638
content:
The Act titled "Department of Homeland Security Headquarters Consolidation Accountability Act of 2015" requires the Secretary to provide information on the implementation of the enhanced plan for the Department headquarters consolidation project within the National Capital Region to Congress within 120 days of enactment. This information should include a proposed occupancy plan for the consolidation project. The Department of Homeland Security is required to provide detailed information on the headquarters consolidation project, including the specific operations and offices to be located at the site, projected number of employees, seat-to-staff ratio, migration schedule, assessment of current vs. future real property needs, and a construction plan for the St. Elizabeths campus. The Department of Homeland Security must provide detailed information on the headquarters consolidation project, including migration schedule estimates, cost savings, and a plan for the leased portfolio in the National Capital Region. The Department of Homeland Security must provide detailed information on the headquarters consolidation project, including the number of employees, rentable square feet leased per year, timing and lease terms, and cost analysis of leasing versus consolidating functions on Government-owned space. The Comptroller General will review cost and schedule estimates for the headquarters consolidation project to assess their quality and reliability. A report will be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the estimates being submitted. Definitions include the Administrator of General Services and the appropriate committees of Congress. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific committees in the House and Senate. The term "Department" refers to the Department of Homeland Security. The term "National Capital Region" is defined under title 10, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 
Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States, who is also the President of the Senate.
